content: How can I help you today?

I'm not really sure where to start. My wife thought it might be a good idea for me to talk to someone, but honestly, I’m here mostly because she pushed me to come. Things have just been really overwhelming at home.

It sounds like there's been a lot on your plate lately, and you’re here because your wife cares about you and wanted to encourage you to talk. Feeling overwhelmed can be tough. What’s been going on at home that’s been so challenging for you?

Our son has been struggling a lot with behavioral issues, and it feels like it's driving a wedge between my wife and me. We're constantly at odds over how to handle it, and it's affecting everything—our marriage, our time with our daughter, even my ability to focus at work. I just don’t know how to fix it, and it’s wearing me down.

That sounds incredibly difficult—navigating your son’s challenges, feeling tension in your marriage, and trying to keep everything else together at the same time. It seems like you’re carrying a lot on your shoulders right now. How have you been managing through all of this?

Honestly, I'm not sure I’ve been managing at all. Mostly, I just feel stuck. I try to push through each day, but it’s like I’m constantly on edge, and I can’t focus on anything—not work, not my family, not even things I used to enjoy.

It sounds like you’re feeling trapped in this cycle, where everything feels heavy and overwhelming, and you’re not getting the space to even enjoy the things that once mattered to you. That must be really exhausting. What do you think has been the hardest part of all this for you?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing my family. I’m supposed to be the one holding things together, helping my wife, being there for my kids, but I just feel like I’m constantly falling short. Seeing how it’s affecting everyone, especially my wife and son, has been the toughest part for me.

It sounds like you deeply care about your family and want so much to be there for them. Feeling like you're falling short must be incredibly painful, especially when you value being that strong, supportive presence for everyone. What do you think has been keeping you going, even in the midst of all of this?

I’m honestly not sure what’s keeping me going—it just feels like I have no other choice but to keep pushing forward. I guess a part of me still hopes that things can get better for my son and my family, even though I don’t see how right now. Maybe that tiny bit of hope is what's keeping me from completely falling apart.

That hope you’re holding on to shows just how much you care about your family and how much you’re willing to fight for things to improve, even when it’s hard to see the way forward. It takes a lot of strength to keep going in tough times. What do you think could help nurture that hope or at least make all of this feel a little more manageable?

Honestly, I don’t really know. I mean, I guess having some kind of support would help, or maybe figuring out how to actually help my son so things could calm down at home. But even thinking about where to start with all of that feels overwhelming.

It sounds like you’re feeling pulled in so many directions that even the idea of taking the first step feels like too much right now. Wanting support and hoping to help your son shows how much you care, and it’s clear you’re trying to figure out what’s best for everyone. What would it feel like to explore some small ways we could make things feel less overwhelming for you?
Possibly small steps where I can feel like I'm not drowning? I think I'd consider that. But I just don’t know where to even start or how any of this could actually get better.

It’s understandable to feel unsure about where to begin, especially when so much feels out of your control. Taking small, manageable steps can be a way to step back from that "drowning" feeling and begin making space for change, little by little. Before we explore any steps, is there anything else about what you’re going through that you feel is important to talk about right now?
I think that about covers it. It’s just hard not knowing where to start or how to make a difference.
